Package com.egehurturk.handlers

Class HttpController

java.lang.Object
com.egehurturk.handlers.HttpController
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Runnable
public class HttpController
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Closeable, java.lang.Runnable
Manager class for handling Socket object client. Using the BufferedReader, this class access the HTTP Request (since HTTP) and parses it. Any Socket object that is accepted by ServerSocket is passed into this class by constructor.

One convenient way to use this class is creating an infinite loop inside the method that constructs this class, and passes the Socket client in the constructor.

This class is responsible for managing the connection. The HttpServer.start() creates an instances of this class and with a client Socket argument, and then runs this with Executor.execute(Runnable) method. This makes the server threaded

Implements the Runnable interface and a run method for making the server threaded. Every work that is done inside the run method executes in another Thread.

This class uses HttpRequest object and HttpResponse to implement the lifecycle of http requests. Any error or exception associated with these classes are located inside com.egehurturk.exceptions

    • run

      public void run()
      About handlers:

      Built-in to system, there is a one HttpHandler installed that is on path /*, which is the default path. This handler listens to all requests (specifically GET) and then responds to the request from the given request's path and finding the relevant HTML file from the local system path. However, if there exists a handler that handles, e.g. GET /hello, then this new handler will override the existing behaviour of the default handler, HttpHandler Priority levels are:

      • MOST PRIORITIZED: /
      • LEAST PRIORITIZED: /* (default)

      Specified by:
      run in interface java.lang.Runnable
